title: 113_hr4708
content: The Act titled "Human Trafficking Fraud Enforcement Act of 2014" establishes an Office for Tax Law Enforcement related to human trafficking and the promotion of commercial sex acts. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish an office within the Internal Revenue Service to investigate and prosecute violations of the internal revenue laws related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. This includes specific criminal provisions listed in title 18 and title 8 of the United States Code. The office established under subsection (a) will cooperate with the Department of Justice and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in combating human trafficking and commercial sex acts. The Secretary of the Treasury must report on enforcement activities to relevant congressional committees within one year of the Act's enactment. The office established under subsection (a) will make recommendations for statutory changes to aid in future prosecutions. Whistleblower awards under the Internal Revenue Code may be given to victims of human trafficking. $4,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2015 for the office's operations. The office established under subsection (a) is authorized to receive appropriations for fiscal years 2015 and 2016 based on tax collections and penalties imposed under the Internal Revenue Code. Any unexpended amounts will be transferred to the Crime Victims Fund. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN CRIMINAL MONETARY PENALTIES. Increase in criminal monetary penalties under Section 7201 of the Internal Revenue Code for attempts to evade or defeat tax related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. Penalties increased to $500,000 ($1,000,000 for higher amounts) and potential imprisonment extended to 10 years. For willful failure to file return, supply information, or pay tax, penalties have been increased under Section 7203 of the Internal Revenue Code to $50,000. Additionally, penalties for failure to file related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts have also been increased. The penalties for willful failure to file return, supply information, or pay tax have been amended to increase penalties for failure related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts under Section 7203 of the Internal Revenue Code. Section 7203(a) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to replace "this section" with "this subsection." Section 7206 is also amended to include a new subsection for fraud and false statements related to tax from human trafficking and commercial sex acts, increasing penalties to $500,000 and 5 years. Section 7206 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase penalties for fraud and false statements related to tax to $500,000 and 5 years. Penalties may be applied in addition to other penalties, with an increase in monetary limitation for underpayment or overpayment of tax due to fraud. The amendments increase penalties for tax fraud and false statements to $500,000 and 5 years. Funds are appropriated to assist crime victims, and the amendments apply to actions after the enactment of the Act.
